questions.question: Of the following, what access control model is MOST likely used by default on most operating systems?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Discretionary access control

A system that employs Discretionary Access Controls (DAC) allows the owner to control and define access to that object. All objects have owners, and access control is based on the discretion or decision of the owner. Most operating systems, including Windows and Linux, use DAC by default. In Windows systems, data owners can adjust file permissions by right-clicking a file and selecting the security tab. In Linux systems, data owners can adjust file permissions by using the chmod and chown commands.

Mandatory Access Control (MAC) uses classification and labels to define user access. MAC is more likely found within a government agency or military. However, it is expensive and difficult to maintain, so it is not found everywhere within the government. It is only used when the security of the data demands it. 

Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) maps a subject’s role with their needed operations and tasks. RBAC is commonly found within organizations. However, the question is about the operating systems. Systems like Windows uses DAC. 

User Account Control (UAC) is not an access control model. It is used in Windows systems to elevate privileges when running a program.

questions.question: A security assessor has been hired by senior management to try and evaluate what types of attacks are targeting the organization. The assessor wants to compile a sample of specific attacks that malicious actors are currently employing. Of the following, what will the assessor MOST likely do?

choices.text: Deploy a Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Deploy a honeypot

A honeypot is a system designed to lure attackers by intentionally weakening the security of the system. Honeypots lure attackers away from the production environment and help identify attack methods and the attacker's identity. Administrators of honeypots need to be careful not to solicit attackers into attacking a honeypot, as this is considered entrapment and is illegal.

A vulnerability scan would tell the assessor that there are weaknesses such as unpatched systems or a lot of open ports, although it would not inform the assessor of the attacks that are targeting the organization.

A penetration test takes the vulnerability scan to the next level and confirms that the identified vulnerabilities are actually attackable, but again this test will not inform the assessor of attacks that are targeting the organization.

A Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) is the next best answer after the honeypot. The logs that are sent to the SIEM can be used to identify what has been going on within the systems found throughout the business. Watching the attackers behavior within a honeypot could tell the assessor more about the attackers targeting the organization.

questions.question: Kyle is a server administrator for an Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) company. One of his clients has asked him to mask their email server IP address to appear different to devices on other networks. Of the following, what technology is Kyle MOST likely to use?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Network Address Translation (NAT)

Network Address Translation (NAT) is used to translate between two IP addresses. Typically, NAT is enabled on a router connected to the internet. The router will translate all the internal IP addresses to a public IP address when outgoing connections are made and translate the return traffic back to the private IP address.

A Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) is a virtualized network environment within a cloud computing platform, such as Amazon Web Services (AWS) or Microsoft Azure. It allows users to create isolated sections of the cloud where they can deploy resources like virtual machines, databases, and applications.

A Virtual Private Network (VPN) is a technology that allows users to establish a secure and encrypted connection over a public network, such as the internet. It enables users to access resources and services securely while maintaining privacy and confidentiality. Protocol used to create a VPN are Transport Layer Security (TLS), Secure Shell (SSH), and Internet Protocol Security (IPSec).

Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) is a network protocol used to automatically assign Internet Protocol (IP) addresses and other network configuration parameters to devices on a network. It simplifies the management of IP addresses and reduces configuration errors.

questions.question: In the United States, the Department of Defense (DoD) often requires that Secret and Top Secret information be stored and processed in a Sensitive Compartmented Information Facility (SCIF). A SCIF is a secure room that acts as a faraday cage. Of the following, what standard will a SCIF MOST likely have to comply with?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: TEMPEST

TEMPEST is a military standard referring to electromagnetic emissions that can be intercepted by a system attacker. The emissions are intercepted from a distance because devices emit electromagnetic frequencies as they transmit data. TEMPEST requires special shielding to reduce the risk of attackers intercepting electronic emissions because they stop the leakage of electromagnetic impulses.

Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) is a Microsoft command line tools. COMSEC is the practice of securing communications in all the ways necessary. Torrent is used to refer to streaming services that can be free to use.

questions.question: When discussing the Statement on Standards for Attestation Engagements (SSAE-18), which type of Service Organization Control (SOC) report is MOST likely intended for public release?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: SOC-3

A common auditing standard is the Statement on Standards for Attestation Engagements (SSAE-18) and provides Service Organization Control (SOC) reports called SOC-1, SOC-2, and SOC-3. A SOC-3 could be considered a seal of approval from the audit company.

  • SOC-1 reports focus on the financial reports of the customer to look at the financial damage that can be caused by the service organization. SOC-2 reports focus on more. There are five key aspects that are analyzed: 1) security, 2) confidentiality, 3) processing integrity, 4) availability, and 5) privacy. 
  • Both SOC-1 and SOC-2 have two types. Type one is a point in time, and type two is over a span of time. 
  • A SOC-3 report has a similar scope to a SOC-2 report; however, a SOC-3 report is written so it can be distributed to anyone. A SOC-3 report is generally much smaller than a SOC-2 report. A SOC-3 could be considered a seal of approval from the audit company.

There is no SOC-4 report.

questions.question:
Sam is a network engineer for a midsized manufacturing organization and stumbled on sensitive documents between their boss and HR. The documents said that the organization would terminate Sam’s employment at the end of the quarter due to the recent economic downturn. This disgruntled Sam, so they decided to configure critical systems to progressively fail and crash once their Single Sign-On (SSO) account was disabled. A few days after they were terminated, all core routers dropped their routing tables and crashed the entire network, resulting in massive financial losses.

Of the following, what BEST describes this type of attack?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: A logic bomb

Logic bombs are programs or code that execute when certain conditions are met. It is common for IT or development personnel to hide malicious programs somewhere in a computer network that executes if their user account is ever disabled.

A buffer overflow occurs when a program tries to store more data in a buffer (temporary storage area) than it can hold. This can lead to data corruption, crashes, or even security vulnerabilities if exploited maliciously.

A computer virus is a type of malicious software that can replicate itself and infect other files or systems. It is designed to spread and cause damage, such as corrupting data, stealing information, or disrupting computer operations.

A fuzzer, also known as a fuzz testing tool, is a software testing technique used to discover vulnerabilities and bugs in programs or systems. It works by sending malformed or unexpected input (fuzz) to the target application, aiming to trigger errors, crashes, or unexpected behavior. Fuzzers are commonly used in security testing to identify weaknesses in software that could be exploited by attackers.

questions.question: Justine has been asked to test newly acquired software for vulnerabilities by sending randomly generated or specially crafted inputs into the software. Of the following, what type of testing has Justine MOST likely been asked to conduct?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Fuzz testing

Fuzz testing is a technique used to find flaws or vulnerabilities by sending randomly generated or specially crafted inputs into the software. There are two types of fuzzers: mutation (Dumb) fuzzers and generational (Intelligent) fuzzers. Mutation fuzzers mutate input to create fuzzed input. Generational fuzzers create fuzzed input based on what type of program is being fuzzed.

Interface testing is a type of software testing that focuses on verifying the interactions and communication between different software modules, components, systems, or subsystems. The goal of interface testing is to ensure that data and control flow correctly across these interfaces and that they behave as expected.

Gray or partial box testing is a software testing technique that combines elements of both open (formerly white) box testing (testing based on internal code structure) and closed (formerly black) box testing (testing based on external behavior and specifications). In gray or partial box testing, testers have limited knowledge of the internal workings of the software, such as its code and algorithms, but they have access to some information that is typically available to end-users or system administrators.

Dynamic software testing refers to the process of evaluating and validating software applications by executing them and observing their behavior in real time. Unlike static testing, which analyzes code without execution, dynamic testing involves running the software to detect defects, assessing functionality, and ensuring that it meets specified requirements. This type of testing is crucial for identifying runtime errors, validating functionality, and assessing performance characteristics.

questions.question:
Ann Marie is a file server administrator at a midsized manufacturing organization. Her boss notifies her that the company has received a court order that says their competitor is suing them for patent violations. The court order explicitly states that any organization documents regarding a specific product must not be deleted and needs to be turned over to the court.

Of the following, what BEST describes the process of identifying and producing the data requested in this type of order?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: e-Discovery

Electronic Discovery (e-Discovery) is a term used to describe the process of identifying and producing Electronically Stored Information (ESI) requested by a court subpoena.

A litigation hold, also known as a legal hold, is a process that an organization uses to preserve all forms of relevant information when litigation is reasonably anticipated. It is a crucial step in the legal process to ensure that electronic and paper records, emails, documents, and other data that could be relevant to a legal case are not destroyed, altered, or lost. This preservation is essential for complying with legal discovery requirements, which may occur during lawsuits, investigations, or audits.

Data forensics, often referred to as digital forensics, is the practice of collecting, analyzing, and preserving data from digital devices in a way that is legally admissible. It's used to investigate and uncover evidence in various contexts, including criminal and civil legal cases, cybersecurity incidents, and unauthorized data access or data breaches. The field encompasses a wide range of digital devices and data sources, including computers, smartphones, tablets, network traffic, and cloud storage services.

A subpoena inquiry involves the legal process where a subpoena is issued to compel an individual or organization to provide documents, to provide evidence, or to testify on a matter under investigation or in a legal proceeding. Subpoenas are formal legal documents issued under the authority of a court or a legal body, signaling the recipient's mandatory compliance.

questions.question: Jordan works for the governments tax service agency and uses a special device to authenticate. The device has a digital certificate and a small microproccesser. It uses a challenge-response mechanism to release the certificate. Of the following, what is MOST likely the device that Jordan uses to authenticate?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Smart card

Smart cards are credit card-sized devices that contain a microprocessor. The smart card typically contains an encrypted private key issued through a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) system that the authenticating environment trusts. When the smart card is inserted into a reader, the user must enter a PIN before the smart card releases the private key. Smart cards can be programmed to wipe themselves if a PIN is entered incorrectly too many times.

Asynchronous and synchronous tokens do not contain digital ceritficates. Both types of tokens will generate unique numbers that can be used to authenticate to a system. They use symmetric algorithms to create numbers. The synchronous tokens also use time for authentication as the asynchronous tokens use a challenge response system.

Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) badges do not usually contain digital certificates either. Normally they are going to store information and are commonly used to open doors when arriving at the office.

questions.question: What is needed MOST to provide accountability for a system?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Identification & Authentication

Accountability relies on the effectiveness of identification and authentication, but it does not require effective authorization. 

After users are identified and authenticated, accountability mechanisms like audit logs track their activity. Accountability creates an audit trail for each user’s actions. It is impossible to make the audit trail if the system cannot identify and authenticate each user. The core to access control is Identification, Authentication, Authorization, Auditing (or Accounting) — IAAA:

  • Identification is where the user claims to be someone through something like the use of a User IDentification (UserID).
  • Authentication is the verification or validation of the user’s identity claim. This is done through the three factors of authentication. 1) Knowledge, 2) Possession, and 3) Biometrics.
  • Authorization is the granting of access and specific permissions.
  • Auditing (or Accounting) is the creation of logs to record what occurred in the first three steps.

The core of this question is that the company needs to know who accessed the system and then took specific actions. The identification and authentication provides proof of who accessed the system (to some level).

Identification without authentication does not prove who accessed the system; therefore, the other answer options are incorrect.

questions.question: A security assessor has audited many organizations throughout their career and has recently been hired by a bank to conduct a System and Organization Control (SOC) 2 audit. During the reporting phase of the audit, what is LEAST likely to be included in the final report?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Competitor comparisons

Auditors should not include any details regarding previous audits to their customers. Auditors should be required to sign a NonDisclosure Agreement (NDA) to discourage them from ever disclosing customer information. Auditors are in a unique position where they are often exposed to the inner workings of organizations that are director competitors.

An audit report of any kind should include an executive summary of all the work and findings that are a result of the audit. That report should include information regarding the methodologies that were used during the audit. 

The auditor should also include recommendations that the corporation should take for any systems that have any findings. 

The auditor should understand the systems that they are auditing, the questions they are asking, and the information and security that should be in place. They are then in a position to make recommendations.

questions.question: The Bell-LaPadula security model is MOST likely concerned with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Confidentiality

The Bell-LaPadula model is lattice-based and is a highly specialized security model whose sole function is confidentiality and limiting access; it has no other substantial functions. The Bell-LaPadula model was developed to formalize the U.S. Department of Defense's (DoD) multi-level security policy.

Clark-Wilson is an integrity-focused model that relies on separating duties and separating subjects from objects. Subjects access and modify objects indirectly through an interface or program. This is known as the access triple.

Biba is an integrity model that prevents subjects with lower security levels from writing to objects at higher security levels.

If authentication is the goal, all three of these models are not related. Authentication is the process of verifying or validating a claimed identity. This can be done with password, tokens, fingerprints, and so on.

Transition state is a term that applies to the Bell-LaPadula and Biba models. Transition state is what occurs when actions are taken by the subject on the object.

questions.question: The idea that something negative may occur with the addition of likelihood and the impact on the organization will occur is BEST described as?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Risk

When quantifying risk, it can be defined as the possibility or likelihood that a vulnerability will be exploited and its resulting impact. Risk is viewed as the possibility that something could happen to damage, destroy, or disclose data or other resources with a discussion of the consequence to the organization. Risk assessment and management are used to reduce risk to an acceptable level.

A vulnerability is a weakness or flaw in a system. When a threat agent exploits a vulnerability, it can cause loss. Vulnerabilities could be flaws in a system or flaws in a process. 

A threat is the circumstance or event that can negatively impact the corporation and their ability to pursue their mission.

An attack occurs when a threat agent attempts to exploit a vulnerability in a system to bring about a threat..

questions.question: Pawel is a network engineer for a midsized manufacturing organization. The security manager has asked him to implement 802.1AE. Of the following, 802.1AE most likely does NOT provide what?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Availability

802.1AE, also known as MACsec, is not used to protect or provide availability in any way.

802.1AE is an Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) standard that provides confidentiality, authentication, and integrity at the data link layer of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model. MACsec adds additional headers to the frame that identify that it has been protected with MACsec.

questions.question: When discussing wireless security, which protocol FIRST introduced Forward Secrecy (FS)?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Wi-Fi Protected Access 3 (WPA3)

Forward Secrecy (FS), sometimes referred to as Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS), is used to prevent the compromise of a long-term secret key from affecting the confidentiality of past transmissions. For example, suppose an attacker compromised a private key used by an asymmetric algorithm to exchange a symmetric encryption key. In that case, the attacker could decrypt all transmissions they have recorded.

WPA3 replaces Pre-Shared Keys (PSK) with Simultaneous Authentication of Equals (SAE). SAE uses zero-knowledge proof instead of sending a hash of the password to the access point. WPA3 uses the Dragonfly Key Exchange, similar to Diffie–Hellman, to exchange keys and provides Forward Secrecy (FS). Like WPA2, WPA3 still uses AES-CCMP to encrypt all wireless transmissions.

WEP was designed to provide confidentiality and privacy for wireless communications by encrypting data transmitted over a Wi-Fi network. WEP relies on static keys, which are not regularly changed, making it vulnerable to key compromise and unauthorized access. WEP's reuse of IVs can lead to predictable encryption patterns and facilitate attacks, such as the IV collision attack.

questions.question:
You are performing a business impact analysis for your organization and need to calculate the Annualized Loss Expectancy (ALE) if an earthquake damaged your building. You estimate the building is worth $250,000 and that if an earthquake hits the building, it will lose 90% of its value. In the past 200 years, two earthquakes have hit the town the building is located in. 

Based on this information, what is the ALE?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: $2,250

Annualized Loss Expectancy (ALE) measures exactly a one-year financial loss an asset may suffer from a specifically identified threat. The formula for ALE is Single Loss Expectancy (SLE) * Annual Rate of Occurrence (ARO), and it is used to determine risk and insurance requirements based on the potential for failure.

The formula for SLE is Asset Value (AV) * Exposure Factor (EF). The AV is the full monetary value of the asset. The EF is the percentage of expected loss if a threat is realized.

AV = $250,000

EF = .90

SLE = $250,000* .90 = $225,000

ARO = .01 or 2/200 or 1/100 (one time/100 years)

ALE = 225,000 * .01 = $2,250

questions.question: Of the following, which BEST describes how an asynchronous token device operates?

choices.text: By generating unique values at regular intervals
By generating a fixed-length output that cannot be reversed

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: By using a challenge/response mechanism

An asynchronous token device generates a one-time password using a challenge/response mechanism. An example of this could be if a workstation displayed a numerical challenge value. The user would enter the value into the token. The token uses this value to generate a new response value that the user enters into the workstation.

Tokens are considered a type-2 authentication factor.

Synchronous tokens generate unique values at regular intervals.

Generating a fixed-length output that cannot be reversed is a description of how hashing works.

Factoring the product of large primes is a mathematical function that is seen in the Rivest, Shamir, Adelman (RSA) algorithm.

questions.question: When discussing software development, what type of programming is MOST likely to use the concept of a class?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)

Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) relies on the relationship between classes and objects. Objects inherit information from their assigned class. This allows programmers to be more efficient with their code. OOP code scales better and is easier to modify.

Declarative programming basically tells the computer what needs to be done rather than how to do it.

Procedural programming has the foundational idea that programs are sequences of instructions that the computer needs to follow.

Functional programming is a paradigm where the program is told what to do through applying functions.

questions.question: Antonia is designing a website to be used for e-commerce. She decides to use a Structured Query Language (SQL) database to store data for the new system. Her manager requires that the database maintain referential integrity. Of the following, what MUST Antonia do to maintain referential integrity?

choices.text: Ensure the foreign key is equal to a valid primary key of a parent table
Ensure the foreign key is equal to a valid primary key of the same table
Ensure the primary key is a unique value for each tuple in the entire database
Ensure there are no duplicate candidate keys within the same table

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Ensure the foreign key is equal to a valid primary key of a parent table

Referential integrity requires that the foreign key be equal to a valid primary key of a different table. A foreign key is a value that references the primary key of a tuple (a.k.a. a record) in a separate table. The primary key is a unique value for each tuple in a table. There can be no tuples with duplicate primary keys.

It is not necessary for a foreign key to equal a primary key, ever. A primary key identifies a row/tuple in a table. When that is connected in some way to a row/tuple in another table, that primary key is copied into the column/attribute/field called a foreign key in the other table, thus referencing the row in the first table.

The primary key must be unique within a table. There are many many tables within a database. It is not necessary for every row in a database to be uniquely identified. 

Ensuring that there is no duplication within the same table is necessary; this is entity integrity though.

questions.question: Of the following, what MOST likely describes a race condition?

choices.text: Timing the modification of an object before the next process acts on that object
Accepting too much data as input resulting in memory space overflows
When two different input values produce the same hash value
When an attacker sends randomly generated or specially crafted inputs into software

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Timing the modification of an object before the next process acts on that object

Race conditions occur when an attacker modifies an object before the next process acts on that object. This allows the attacker to manipulate an application or operating system into performing actions that would normally not be possible.

For example, assume process A authorizes a user to open a non-critical file, and process B opens the file. Suppose the attacker replaces the non-critical file with a protected file before process A finishes executing. When process B runs the open command, it will open the protected file instead of the non-critical file.

Accepting too much data as input is called a buffer overflow. Buffer overflows could cause a program to crash or execute random code.

If two different inputs hash to the same value that is a collision. It is commonly identified as a birthday attack.

If an attacker sends randomly generated or specially crafted inputs into softward, then this could be a command injection or a Structured Query Language (SQL) injection.

questions.question: Siobhan is designing a database schema for a banking application. Maintaining the integrity of the data written to the database is essential. Of the following, what is MOST crucial for Siobhan to do when designing the database schema?

choices.text: Ensure the database conforms to the properties of ACID
Design the schema in a way that limits aggregation attacks
Ensuring front-end applications are hardened to Structured Query Language (SQL) injection attacks

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Ensure the database conforms to the properties of ACID

Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability (ACID) are a set of properties that ensure data written to the database is accurate and trustworthy.

The following is an explanation of ACID:

  • Atomicity: Ensures that the entire transaction is successful or it is rolled back. If a portion of the transaction fails, everything is rolled back as if none of the transaction took place.
  • Consistency: Ensures that transactions cannot bring the database from a valid state to an invalid state. All records must follow the database rules. For example, records must have a primary key.
  • Isolation: Ensures that concurrent transactions do not interfere with each other.
  • Durability: Ensures that the changes will remain after a transaction is completed and cannot be rolled back.

Ensuring a database schema is scalable is always good to do, but this is an availability topic, not integrity as indicated in the question.

Designing the schema to reduce aggregation attacks would also be good to do, but this is a confidentiality topic.

Ensuring the front-end application is hardened is a different topic than designing a schema. Ensuring that SQL injections are not going to work is also good to do, but it is in the front-end application. Validating the input and blocking SQL commands is critical.

questions.question: You are the network engineer for a large banking organization. Her boss is concerned about data integrity at layer two of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model in their organization's Ethernet network. Of the following, what protocol will you MOST likely use?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: 802.1AE

802.1AE, also known as MACsec, is an Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) standard that provides confidentiality and integrity at the data link layer of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model. MACsec adds additional headers to the frame that identify that it has been protected by MACsec.

Internet Protocol Security (IPSec) is incorrect because it operates at the IP layer of the OSI model. Secure Real Time Protocol (SRTP) is incorrect because it operates at the application layer of the OSI model and is generally used to protect voice communications. WiFi Protected Access 2 (WPA2) is incorrect because it protects wireless connections, not Ethernet connections.

questions.question: Of the following, what BEST describes a technology that creates a fixed-length output that cannot be reversed?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: A hashing algorithm

A hashing algorithm is a one-way mathematical operation that can accept an input value of any length and generate a fixed-length output. The output cannot be mathematically reversed. Hashing algorithms are used to validate a file's or message’s integrity. They are also used to store passwords. A password is hashed, and the authentication server stores the output. The only way to reproduce the hash is to know the original value.

Encryption is actually a two-way process. Encryption takes the plaintext and turns it into ciphertext. The opposite function called decryption turns the ciphertext back into the plaintext. This process is performed using an algorithm and an encryption key, also called a crypto variable. 

A digitital certificate contains a public key, which is one of the two key found in asymmetric encryption algorithms. This is one of the two methods of encryption, the other is symmetric.

questions.question: Of the following, which National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Special Publication (SP) MOST likely establishes a Risk Management Framework (RMF)?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: NIST SP 800-37

NIST SP 800-37 introduces the Risk Management Framework (RMF) and provides guidelines for applying the RMF to information systems and organizations.

NIST SP 800-187 is a guide to Long Term Evolution (LTE) security for cellular network.

NIST SP 800-124 is a guideline to managing mobile devices in enterprises.

NIST SP 800-53 is the Security and Privacy Controls for Information Systems and Organizations.

questions.question: Which security model MOST likely separates subjects from objects and requires objects to be modified through an interface or program?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Clark-Wilson

The Clark-Wilson model focuses on data integrity. It relies on the separation of duties and the separation of subjects from objects. Subjects access and modify objects indirectly through an interface or program. This is known as the access triple and is made up of the subject/program/object. The Clark-Wilson model defines Constrained Data Items (CDI) and integrity verification procedures and confirms Transformation Procedures (TPs).

Biba identifies what actions a subject can take on an object, separated by levels of integrity requirements. K.J. Biba did not identify a control mechanism to be placed between those two, though, as the question is asking for.

Brewer and Nash look to prevent conflicts of interest. This is done by separating subject and objects related to one project from subjects and object related to other projects. This is not quite the separation the question is asking for.

Graham-Denning focuses on securely creating and deleting subjects and objects, not separating them.

questions.question: Of the following, what key exchange is MOST likely used to add Forward Secrecy (FS)?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Diffie–Hellman

Forward Secrecy (FS), sometimes referred to as Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS), is used to prevent the compromise of a long-term secret key from affecting the confidentiality of past transmissions. For example, suppose an attacker compromised a private key used by an asymmetric algorithm to exchange a symmetric encryption key. In that case, the attacker could decrypt all transmissions they have recorded.

To take advantage of FS when using Transport Layer Security (TLS), only cipher suites that use Diffie–Hellman may be allowed. On its own, Diffie–Hellman does not provide authentication. To overcome this, TLS uses Rivest–Shamir–Adleman (RSA) or DSA to authenticate the server prior to key exchange. Beginning in TLS 1.3, FS is forced since Diffie–Hellman is the option for key exchange.

Message Digest 5 (MD5) is a hashing algorithm. It is only used to verify the integrity of data. It is not used for key exchange.

A PSK eliminates the need for a key exchange algorithm. When the key is pre-shared, it is manually entered into the end stations. This is common in our homes. When a visitor comes over and they are given the key to the wireless network, that is a Pre-Shared Key (PSK).

questions.question:
When discussing Domain Name System Security Extensions (DNSSEC), the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is responsible for creating and maintaining cryptographic keys used to sign and validate responses of root DNS servers. ICANN distributes parts of a special decryption key to seven individuals that can be used to re-generate a Key Signing Key (KSK) in the event of a disaster. To recreate the KSK, a minimum of five of the seven individuals must come together. 

Of the following, this is MOST likely an example of what?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: M of N control

M of N control requires that a minimum number of authorized users (M) be present out of all authorized users (N) before performing a function. For example, a dual custody safe may have three keys and require two of the three keys to be present before opening. M of N control is a form of Split Knowledge. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) uses M of N control to ensure that an unauthorized Key Signing Key (KSK) cannot be generated.

Separation of Duties (SoD) is a fundamental principle in cybersecurity and internal control systems that aims to reduce the risk of fraud, errors, and unauthorized activities by distributing tasks and responsibilities among different individuals or roles within an organization. The concept of SoD is based on the idea that no single individual should have complete control over a critical process or system, which helps prevent conflicts of interest and ensures checks and balances are in place.

Software escrow is a legal arrangement involving a third party, known as an escrow agent, that holds and manages the source code, documentation, and other intellectual property assets related to software on behalf of the software's owner (licensor) and a beneficiary (licensee). The purpose of software escrow is to provide assurance to the licensee that they can access and use the software in the event of specific triggering events or circumstances that may prevent the licensor from fulfilling their obligations.

Mandatory Access Control (MAC) is a security model used in computer systems and networks to enforce strict access controls based on predefined security policies. In MAC, access decisions are determined by the system rather than by the user or process requesting access. The system matches the classification of the resource to the clearance of the user and the corporate policy to make the determination of appropriate access. This contrasts with Discretionary Access Control (DAC), where access decisions are typically made by the owner or creator of the resource.

questions.question: Of the following, what is MOST likely considered the best defense against rainbow tables?

choices.text: Encryption modes that utilize an Initialization Vector (IV)

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Using salts

A salt is a random value that is added to passwords when generating a hash. Salts can help prevent the disclosure of passwords even if the hash is disclosed because the attacker needs to know the salt and password before finding a match.

The Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol (CHAP) uses a Number used ONCE (NONCE) in the same way that a salt is used. It is done to protect from replay attacks.

The Diffie-Hellman (DH) key negotiation protocol is used to exchange symmetric protocols; it is in no way connected to the concept of passwords, rainbow tables, or salts.

Encryption modes that use IVs are modes of operation for symmetric algorithms. Modes that use IVs include Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) and Output Feedback Mode (OFM).

questions.question: Of the following, which protocol or standard is LEAST likely to provide authentication?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: OAuth

Open Authorization (OAuth) is an authorization framework that allows users to grant websites access to their information without providing a password. OAuth can be used by third parties to access a user’s email contacts and other information the user delegates to the third party. OAuth does not provide authentication.

Open IDentification (OpenID), Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML), and Open IDentification (OpenID) Connect all provide authentication. OpenID has the function of identification. It is not useful if the subjects just present their identification unless there is also authentication information (passwords, etc.) presented with it to prove their identity. SAML issues tokens after the identification of the subjects is confirmed.

questions.question:
A penetration tester who specializes in physical security has been hired by a large insurance company to assess their physical security and evaluate other vulnerabilities that could be exploited. The tester wants to see if they can steal user credentials. When the employees come back from lunch, the tester decides to tailgate into the building, posing as a janitor.

Of the following, what type of attack is MOST likely to remain undetected and succeed now that the tester knows how to gain physical access to the environment?

choices.text: Steal documents from a secure shred bin
Brute force credentials on an open workstation
Attempt to connect to the network and establish a reverse tunnel to a remote server

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Deploy a physical key logger

A key logger is a device that connects between a keyboard and the computer. It records keystrokes and saves them. Key loggers are extremely difficult to detect since they are presented to the operating system as a keyboard. Security managers should periodically sweep their environments and look for unauthorized devices such as key loggers.

Stealing documents from the shred bin is not that likely to reveal any user credentials; it could, but a key logger definitely would uncover those credentials.

Brute forcing the credentials from an open workstation has two problems. It is more likely that someone will question why the penetration tester is there before they succeed in brute forcing the password. Brute force in this scenario is to guess one password after the next until one is found to work from the user's interface. The second problem is that there is likely that the account will be locked after just three or five tries, requiring many visits back to keep trying.

Attempting to connect to the network will not reveal the user's credentials. It would just be a connection to the remote server.

questions.question: Of the following, which is LEAST likely to be a Key Risk Indicator (KRI)?

choices.text: Decrease in closed service tickets per employee

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Decrease in closed service tickets per employee

A decrease in closed service tickets per employee is a Key Performance Indicator (KPI). Key Performance Indicator (KPI) helps to evaluate a process's health, while a Key Risk Indicator (KRI) serves as more of a warning of increased risk.

An increase in Intrusion Detection System (IDS) alerts is a possible indication that attacks are increasing—that would be a risk indication.

A decreased number of installed security patches, or percentage of installed patches, would also be an indication of risk. A decrease in patches could mean an increase in vulnerabilities.

Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) values are used to indicate how severe a known vulnerability is. An increase in the number of higher CVSS values would be an indication that the systems within the network are at a higher risk of attack.

questions.question: When discussing recovery operations, what is the calculated amount of time that a process is to be restored by called?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Recovery time objective

Recovery Time Objective (RTO) is the duration of time that a business process must be restored. This time frame must fit within the Maximum Tolerable Downtime (MTD). There are many things that must occur when a critical business process has been interrupted. If the interruption is because of something like a fire, it is necessary to ensure that all people are evacutated out of the burning building first. 

So, the portion of the MTD that is allocated to doing the work of recovering the critical business process is called the RTO. It is an objective that is being calculated now while things are working, and it is the time that the team has to do the work of recovery. (The memory jogger is to read RTO in the opposite direction OTR ... the objective is this time if for recovery).

The recovery point objective (RPO) is the amount or extent of data loss that can be tolerated by critical business systems. 

Maximum Tolerable Downtime (MTD) is the maximum length of time a business function can remain down without causing irreparable harm to the organization. 

A Business Continuity Plan (BCP) works with a Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP) to plan for and recover from a disaster.

questions.question: Of the following, what BEST describes an Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU)?

choices.text: Physical circuits that perform bitwise operations on binary numbers
Physical circuits configured in a parallel structure to accelerate the creation of images

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Physical circuits that perform bitwise operations on binary numbers

The Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) is a series of physical circuits that perform bitwise operations on binary numbers. The circuits are built using logic gates made from transistors.

The Central Processing Unit (CPU) is made up of the ALU and Registers. Registers are temporary storage for instruction sets to be processed by the ALU. 

Random-Access Memory (RAM) stores application instructions and outputs from the CPU/ALU. 

Physical circuits configured in a parallel structure to accelerate the creation of images is a Graphics Processing Unit (GPU)
